Detailed Description

template<unsigned D, typename N = double>
class VecMath::Matrix< D, N >

Matrix class that uses template metaprogramming to speed up multiplications.

Matrix<D, N>: a DxD matrix of numbers of type N

Parameters:
D dimension of the matrix
N numerical type of the matrix elements
Author:
Helge Preuss <scout@hyperspace-travel.de>
A matrix class speeding up matrix multiplications by using template metaprogramming to let the compiler unroll and optimize the multiplication loops

Todo:
why does the 100 fold speed increase come and go? why does it only work for dimensions up to 4?
some clue:
when print() is called after NLOOP multiplications, runtime performance drops significantly. this is the case for templatized version as well as with the for loop. roughly speaking, print() incurs an overhead of a second for both versions. funny thing is, print () is called AFTER the timing has taken place.
the performance drop with print() has vanished after getting the initialization correct (looping from D-1 to 0 instead of looping from D)
err well, this in not true... it has only vanished *sometimes*. I assume that gcc does the calculations only when the elements are in fact accessed after the calculation, otherwise it optimizes them away.
Todo:
a corresponding vector class and member function for transformation of vectors
Todo:
const-correctness everywhere
Todo:
templatize copy loop in Matrix (const N a[D][D])
Todo:
drop D_ as template parameter for inner classes where possible
there is a problem with specializations in inner classes, which don't have any template parameters at all: 
            template <>                                             // error!
                struct ConstructLoop<0, 0> {
                  static void row_loop (N a[D][D]) { a[0][0] = (N)1;
                }
workaround <news:718f76ba.0305081256.6969e6ae@posting.google.com> 
            // workaround class
            template <typename S> struct inner {
                template <typename T> static int apply(int) { generic action here }
            };

            template <typename T> struct outer {
                template <typename S> int specialized(int a) {
                    return inner<S>::template apply<T>(a);
                }
            };

            // specialize your workaround class for each type
            template <> struct inner< double > {
                template <typename T> static int apply(int) {
                    // code for outer<T>::specialized< double >
                }
            };

            // more specialization's of inner<> as necessary.
Todo:
specializations of inner classes - do they really have to be declared? (seems so)
whittle them down to the bare minimum anyways

template<unsigned D, typename N>
VecMath::Matrix< D, N >::Matrix ( unsigned  axis1,
unsigned  axis2,
N  alpha 
) [inline]

Construct a rotation matrix.

creates a rotation about axes ii and jj of angle Theta

Parameters:
ii first (row) index
jj second (column) index
Theta rotation angle
For the rotation angle alpha around the axis defined by axis1 and axis2.
e.g. in 3 dimensions: axis1 = 1, axis2 = 2 => rotation around dimension 0 ( = x -axis)
Parameters:
axis1 first dimension to define the rotation direction
axis2 first dimension to define the rotation direction
alpha rotation angle
D dimension of the matrix
N (Numeric) type of the elements

VecMath::Matrix< D, N >::Matrix ( const N *  a  )  [inline]

construct a matrix from a one-dimensional array of N 's

this matrix will very probably not use the blessings and optimizations of template metaprogramming, because the compiler cannot see its contents

template<unsigned D, typename N>
VecMath::Matrix< D, N > VecMath::Matrix< D, N >::operator* ( const Matrix< D, N > &  other  )  [inline]

Matrix multiplication.

Uses the class static function Multiply<D>::multiply() to do the loop over the elements and perform the multiplications.
Does not change this.

Returns:
this multiplied by other
Parameters:
other The matrix with which to multiply this

References VecMath::Matrix< D, N >::data_.

template<unsigned D, typename N>
VecMath::Matrix< D, N > VecMath::Matrix< D, N >::operator*= ( const Matrix< D, N > &  other  )  [inline]

Matrix multiplication.

Uses the class static function Multiply<D>::multiply() to do the loop over the elements and perform the multiplications.
Replaces this with this * other

Parameters:
other The matrix with which to multiply this
